{{short description|American singer-songwriter}} {{Use mdy dates|date=December 2019}} {{Infobox musical artist | name = Sonya Isaacs | image = Sonya_Isaacs.jpg | caption = | image_size = | background = solo_singer | birth_name = Sonya Melissa Isaacs{{cite web|url=http://repertoire.bmi.com/writer.asp?blnWriter=True&blnPublisher=True&blnArtist=True&page=1&fromrow=1&torow=25&querytype=WriterID&keyid=167141&keyname=ISAACS+SONYA+MELISSA&CAE=223528489&Affiliation=BMI|title=Search results for Isaacs, Sonya Melissa|work=[[Broadcast Music Incorporated]]|access-date=December 23, 2010}} | birth_place = | birth_date = {{birth date and age|1974|07|22}}{{cite journal |date=July 28, 2008 |title=Birthdays |journal=[[Country Weekly]] |volume=15 |issue=15 |pages=62}} | origin = [[LaFollette, Tennessee]], U.S. | instrument = [[singing|Vocals]], [[mandolin]] | genre = Bluegrass, and Southern Gospel | occupation = [[Singing|Singer]], [[songwriter]] | years_active = 1999–present | label = [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]] | current_member_of = [[The Isaacs]] | spouse = {{marriage|[[Jimmy Yeary]]|2009}} }} '''Sonya Melissa Isaacs''' (born July 22, 1974) is an American [[country music|country]], [[Bluegrass music|bluegrass gospel]] and [[Christian music]] singer. Isaacs grew up near [[Morrow, Ohio]], and graduated from [[Little Miami High School (Ohio)|Little Miami High School]] in 1992. Her maternal grandparents are [[The Holocaust in Poland|Polish Jewish Holocaust]] survivors and were liberated from a concentration camp in Germany in 1945.{{cite news |last1=BARCLAY |first1=BRITTANY |title=The Isaacs to bring bluegrass gospel to The Pines |url=https://lufkindailynews.com/news/community/article_94d60ad4-b88c-5651-a672-7ce01b2b7c36.html |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=The Lufkin Daily News |language=en}}{{cite news |last1=Etienne |first1=Vanessa |title=The Isaacs Premiere 'The American Face' Music Video: 'United We Stand' |url=https://people.com/music/isaacs-premiere-the-american-face-music-video-united-we-stand/ |access-date=12 July 2021 |work=PEOPLE.com |language=en}} She has released one album on [[Lyric Street Records]], and has charted five singles on the ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' [[Hot Country Songs]] charts. Three were included on her self-titled debut album, released in 2000. A fourth was a Christmas single included on the label's multi-artist collection ''No Wrapping Required: A Christmas Album''. Her highest-charting single, "No Regrets Yet", peaked at number 36 on the country charts but did not appear on an album. She parted ways with Lyric Street in 2004.{{cite web |url=http://www.allbusiness.com/transportation-communications/communications-radio/4361802-1.html |title=On the Row: Compadre Records Signs Three Artists |access-date=January 4, 2008 |last=Stark |first=Phyllis |date=March 12, 2004 |work=Airplay Monitors}} Isaacs, along with several of her family members, also comprise a [[gospel music]] band called [[The Isaacs]].{{cite web |url=http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20050225200135/http://www.cmt.com/artists/az/isaacs/bio.jhtml |url-status=dead |archive-date=February 25, 2005 |title=The Isaacs biography |access-date=January 4, 2008 |work=[[Country Music Television]]}} Sonya recorded the song "The Battlefield" for the soundtrack to the 2006 film ''[[Broken Bridges]]''. She and [[Vince Gill]] contributed guest vocals to a cover of "[[Misty (song)|Misty]]" on [[Cledus T. Judd]]'s 2007 tribute album ''[[Boogity, Boogity – A Tribute to the Comedic Genius of Ray Stevens]]''. She also sang a duet with [[Dolly Parton]] to "The Angels Rejoiced". Isaacs married singer-songwriter [[Jimmy Yeary]] on December 20, 2009, with whom she co-wrote [[Martina McBride]]'s 2011 single "[[I'm Gonna Love You Through It]]". Isaacs and Yeary have two sons born in 2011 and 2015, and a daughter born in 2017.{{cite web|author=Brad Schmitt |url=http://www.tennessean.com/story/entertainment/2016/08/26/sonya-isaacs-healing-stillborn-birth/89225046/ |title=Sonya Isaacs healing from stillborn birth |publisher=Tennessean.com |access-date=August 26, 2016}} As a member of ''The Isaacs'', Isaacs became a [[List of Grand Ole Opry members|member]] of the [[Grand Ole Opry]] in 2021.{{cite news |title=Ricky Skaggs invites family bluegrass group The Isaacs to become Grand Ole Opry members |url=https://www.tennessean.com/videos/entertainment/2021/08/11/ricky-skaggs-invites-family-bluegrass-group-isaacs-become-grand-ole-opry-members/5566500001/ |access-date=8 March 2022 |work=The Tennessean}}{{cite web |title=Opry in the News: The Isaacs Inducted as Newest Members |url=https://www.opry.com/story/opry-in-the-news-the-isaacs-inducted-as-newest-members/ |website=Grand Ole Opry |access-date=8 March 2022 |language=en}} ==Discography== ===Albums=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! style="width:10em;"| Title ! style="width:18em;"| Album details |- ! scope="row"| ''Sonya Isaacs'' | * Released: October 10, 2000 * Label: [[Lyric Street Records|Lyric Street]] * Format: [[Compact disc|CD]] |} ===Singles=== {| class="wikitable plainrowheaders" style="text-align:center;" |- ! rowspan="2" style="width:16em;"| Single ! rowspan="2"| Year ! colspan="2"| Peak positions ! rowspan="2"| Album |- style="font-size:smaller;" ! width="45"| [[Hot Country Songs|US Country]]
